Label_Description:
Single Product: Generic Drug Name| Strength| Strength Units|Drug Form Description |[package size]  - if applicable
Combination product: Generic Drug Name (each ingredient)| Strength (ingredient 1)| Strength Units (ingredient 1)|"-" |  Strength (ingredient 2)| Strength Units (ingredient 2)|Drug Form Descriptor
Volume Product: Generic Drug Name| Strength| Strength Units|"/" Volume|Drug Form Descripton
Character_Limited_Descriptions:
Drop strength units for all ingredients except for last ingredient strength unit

conjugated = conj
Comments:
50 Character limit excluding package sizes in brackets (DoD allowance 60, VA CMOP allowance 50)
Brand products: will include the Brand name in the Manfuc. description. IF is generic for everything except for NTIs where it will be: generic name (brand name).
Only include salt if there are multiple salts
Products used for compounding will be exceptions to the following business rules and will be reviewed by enterprise team
Include applicator when appropriate. Can shorten to 'app' if the character limit is over 50
Sugar, Alcohol, Dye, Citrate Free: (SF/AF/DF/CF) before drug form [e.g. (SF) oral solution]
Supply_Chain_Considerations: BUOM = lowest available denominator unless the smallest billing quantity is a decimal point. If decimal point then use Inventory Package BUOM (e.g. Inhaler of 6.7 g would need a BUOM of 6.7 g)

Label_Description:
Drug Form Descriptor: inhaler
Include Package Size
Comments:
1. Unique ITEM_ID for each package size
2. Do not include HFA and CFC Free
3. Remove the inh from mcg/inh 
4. Change brackets to parentheses  --> [6.2g] change to (6.2g)
Form_Definitions: A product that is packaged under pressure and contains therapeutically active ingredients that are released upon activation of an appropriate valve system; it is intended for topical application to the skin as well as local application into the nose (nasal aerosols), mouth (lingual aerosols), or lungs (inhalation aerosols).

Comments: Order by EACH
Form_Definitions: A solid dosage form usually in the form of a rectangle.

Label_Description: Drug Form Descriptor: capsule
Form_Definitions: A solid oral dosage form consisting of a shell and a filling.  The shell is composed of a single sealed enclosure, or two halves that fit together and which are sometimes sealed with a band.  Capsule shells may be made from gelatin, starch, or cellulose, or other suitable materials, may be soft or hard, and are filled with solid or liquid ingredients that can be poured or squeezed.

Label_Description:
Drug Form Descriptor: capsule
Include ER description after Drug Name
Include "/12 hour" after Strength Units
Drug Name| ER | Strength| Strength Units|"/12 hour" |Drug Form
Item_Description_Example: aspirin-dipyridamole ER 25 mg-200 mg/12 hr capsule
NDC_Description_Examples:
Item Description: propafenone ER 225 mg/12 hour capsule
NDC Description: Rythmol SR 225 mg/12 hour capsule

Exception Item Description: dilTIAZem SR 90 mg/12 hour capsule
Exception NDC Description: dilTIAZem SR 90 mg/12 hour capsule
Comments:
1. Only use this dosage form if the manufacturer markets the product as a 12-hour formulation. May need to research if Multum does not pull in. If the manufacturer does not indicate it is 12 hours then do not include and use the Cap-ER drug formulation.
2. For most items use ER on the item and NDC description; however if there are multiple formulations of the same medication that have different descriptors then use the Brand descriptor (e.g. XR/SR/LA)
3. The approved exceptions that can have XR/LA/SR: Diltiazem, Nifedipine, Morphine, Methylphenidate, Bupropion, Depakote

Label_Description:
Drug Form: capsule
Include ER description after Drug Name
Include "/24 hour" after Strength Units
Drug Name| ER | Strength| Strength Units|"/24 hour" |Drug Form
NDC_Description_Examples:
Item Description: propranolol ER 80 mg/24 hour capsule
NDC Description: Inderal LA 80 mg/24 hour capsule

Exception Item Description: dilTIAZem CD 120 mg/24 hour capsule
Exception NDC Description: Cardizem CD 120 mg/24 hour capsule
Comments:
1. Only use this dosage form if the manufacturer markets the product as a 24-hour formulation. May need to research if Multum does not pull in. If the manufacturer does not indicate it is 24 hours then do not include and use the Cap-ER drug formulation.
2. For most items use ER on the item and NDC description; however if there are multiple formulations of the same medication that have different descriptors then use the Brand descriptor (e.g. XR/SR/LA)
3. The approved exceptions that can have XR/LA/SR: Diltiazem, Nifedipine, Morphine, Methylphenidate, Bupropion, Depakote

Form_Definitions: No definition for controlled release or targeted release is provided by the FDA or pharmacopoeias.

Form_Definitions: A solid dosage form in which the drug is enclosed within either a hard or soft soluble container made from a suitable form of gelatin, and which releases a drug (or drugs) at a time other than promptly after administration.  Enteric-coated articles are delayed release dosage forms.

2. For most items use ER on the item and NDC description; however if there are multiple formulations of the same medication that have different descriptors then use the Brand descriptor (e.g. XR/SR/LA)

Form_Definitions: A solid dosage form in which the drug is enclosed within either a hard or soft soluble container or "shell" made from a suitable form of gelatin; additionally, the capsule is covered in a designated coating, and which releases a drug (or drugs) in such a manner to allow at least a reduction in dosing frequency as compared to that drug (or drugs) presented as a conventional dosage form.

Label_Description: Drug Form Descriptor: foam
Form_Definitions: A dosage form containing one or more active ingredients, surfactants, aqueous or nonaqueous liquids, and the propellants; if the propellant is in the internal (discontinuous) phase (i.e., of the oil-in-water type), a stable foam is discharged, and if the propellant is in the external (continuous) phase (i.e., of the water-in-oil type), a spray or a quick-breaking foam is discharged.

Form_Definitions: A small medicinal particle or grain made available in its more stable dry form, to be reconstituted with solvent just before dispensing; the granules are so prepared to contain not only the medicinal agent, but the colorants, flavorants, and any other desired pharmaceutic ingredient.

Comments: DIV=0 (PKG_UNIT=g); DIV=1 (PKG_UNIT=EA or mL)
Form_Definitions: A small particle or grain containing a medicinal agent in a dry mixture usually composed of sodium bicarbonate, citric acid, and tartaric acid which, when in contact with water, has the capability to release gas, resulting in effervescence.

Comments: DIV=0 (PKG_UNIT=g); DIV=1 (PKG_UNIT=EA or mL)
Form_Definitions: A small medicinal particle or grain made available in its more stable dry form, to be reconstituted with solvent just before dispensing to form a suspension; the extended release system achieves slow release of the drug over an extended period of time and maintains constant drug levels in the blood or target tissue.

Form_Definitions: A drug delivery system that often contains an adhesive backing that is usually applied to an external site on the body.  Its ingredients either passively diffuse from, or are actively transported from, some portion of the patch.  Depending upon the patch, the ingredients are either delivered to the outer surface of the body or into the body.  A patch is sometimes synonymous with the terms ‘extended release film’ and ‘system’.

Label_Description:
ORAL CONTRACEPTIVES

Drug form: tablet
NDC_Description_Examples:
Item description: desogestrel/EE 0.15 mg-0.03 mg tab (28)
NDC description: Apri (desogetrel/EE) 0.15/0.03 tablet (28)
Comments:
1. remove the 'EA' from the package size and put the package size in '()' so it doesn't get stripped from CMOP and use pkg sz on the item level desc
         - Ex: Desogen 0.5/0.03 tab (28)
2. Remove 'extended cycle'
3.Mark all oral contraceptives needs to be marked as non-divisible (exception: Nuva ring)

2. For most items use ER on the item and NDC description; however if there are multiple formulations of the same medication that have different descriptors then use the Brand descriptor (e.g. XR/SR/LA)

Label_Description: Drug Form: effervescent tablet
Item_Description_Example: citric acid-potassium bicarbonate 20 mEq eff tab
Form_Definitions: A solid dosage form containing mixtures of acids (e.g., citric acid, tartaric acid) and sodium bicarbonate, which release carbon dioxide when dissolved in water; it is intended to be dissolved or dispersed in water before administration.

Label_Description: Drug Form: sublingual tablet
Comments: DIV=0 (nitroglycerin); DIV=1 (all others)

Label_Description: Drug Form: tablet
Comments: DIV=0 (with applicator); DIV=1 (all others)

Label_Description: Drug Form: tape
Comments: Include Package Size if product is not divisible
Form_Definitions: A narrow woven fabric, or a narrow extruded synthetic (such as plastic), usually with an adhesive on one or both sides.

Label_Description: Drug Form: tincture
Comments: DIV=0 (non-oral); DIV=1 (oral)
Form_Definitions: An alcoholic or hydroalcoholic solution prepared from vegetable materials or from chemical substances.

Label_Description: Drug Form: topical wash
